section.title: Introduction
section.p: RamFS is the RAM Filing System. It is a module that, together with FileSwitch and FileCore, provides a RAM-based filing system.
Most of the facilities that you will use with RamFS are in fact provided by FileCore and FileSwitch and, and you should read the chapters on those modules in conjunction with this one.

section.title: Overview
section.p: RamFS is a module that provides the hardware-dependent part of a RAM-based filing system. It uses FileCore, and so conforms to the standards for a module that does so; see the chapter entitled FileCore for details.

command-definition.name: Configure RamFsSize
command-definition.description: Sets the configured amount of memory reserved for the RAM filing system
command-definition.parameter: number of kilobytes of memory reserved
optional term to specify value in kilobytes
number of pages of memory reserved; n ≤ 127

use.p: *Configure RamFsSize sets the configured amount of memory reserved for the RAM Filing System to use (when the RAMFS module is present) after the next hard reset. The default value is 0, which disables the RAM filing system.

command-definition.name: Ram
command-definition.description: Selects the RAM Filing System as the current filing system

use.p: *Ram selects the RAM Filing System as the filing system for subsequent operations. Remember that it is not necessary to switch filing systems if you use the full pathnames of objects. For example, you can refer to objects (on a file server, say) when RamFS is the current filing system.
Memory must have previously been reserved for the RAM filing system; the simplest ways to do so are to use the command , or to use the Task Manager from the desktop.
